elements.content: Thirteen Cd(II)-containing coordination polymers based on the novel tetradentate ligand tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L), namely, [Cd2(L)2(SO4)2(H2O)2]·4H2O (1), [Cd(L)(H2O)2](NO3)2 (2), [Cd(L)(Br)2]·H2O (3), [Cd(L)0.5(L1)] (4), [Cd5(L2)5(H2O)2]·6H2O (5), [CdL3(L)0.5] (6), [CdL4(L)0.5(H2O)]·H2O (7), [Cd2(L5)2(L)]·2H2O (8), [Cd3(L6)2(L)]·4H2O (9), [Cd3(L7)2(L)(H2O)2]·2.5H2O (10), [Cd(HL8)(L)]·0.75H2O (11), [Cd7(L9)3(μ3-OH)2(L)2]·8H2O (12), [Cd2(L10)(L)(H2O)2]·H2O (13), where H2L1 = fumaric acid, H2L2 = adipic acid, H2L3 = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2L4 = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2L5 = 5-OH-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H3L6 = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H3L7 = 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H3L8 = 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H4L9 = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid, and H4L10 = 4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid, have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Compound L·5H2O shows a novel three-dimensional (3D) (3,8)-connected supramolecular architecture with a unique (3·52)2(34·42·56·612·73·8) topology. Compounds 1−3 were isolated by the reactions of L with inorganic anions (SO4 2−, NO3 −, Br−). Compound 1 displays a 4-connected PtS network. Compound 2 exhibits a 3D 4-connected zeolite ABW net, while compound 3 is a two-dimensional (2D) (44)-sql net. Compounds 4−8 were isolated by the reactions of L with organic dicarboxylate ligands. 4 exhibits a 2-fold interpenetrating α-Po net, while 5 shows a noninterpenetrating 3D framework. 6 shows a 3D (65·8) CdSO4-type framework, whereas compound 7 has a different 3D framework with (4·62·72·8)(42·62·7·8) topology. 8 shows a 2D layer structure, which is further extended into a 3D supramolecular framework by the hydrogen bonds. Compounds 9−11 have been obtained by the reactions of L with organic tricarboxylate ligands. In 9, the Cd(II) atoms are bridged by L and L6 ligands to form a 3D structure. In 10, the trinuclear Cd(II) clusters are linked by the L and L7 ligands to generate a chiral 3D α-Po structure. In 11, the Cd(II) centers are connected by the L ligands and the partially deprotonated HL8 ligand to yield a 2D layer structure. Compounds 12 and 13 were synthesized by the reactions of L with different organic tetracarboxylate ligands. In compound 12, the L9 ligands link the Cd(II) centers to form a 3D Cd-L9 framework, and the L ligands further stabilize the 3D structure. In compound 13, L10 ligands coordinate to the Cd(II) atoms in tetradentate mode to generate a 2D layer, which is further linked by L ligands to form a 3D framework. The structural differences of compounds 1−13 indicate that the presence of the different anions play an important role in the resulting structures of the coordination polymers. The infrared spectra and luminescent properties were also investigated for the compounds.

elements.content: Thirteen Cd(II)-containing coordination polymers based on a novel tetradentate ligand tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L) have been successfully synthesized by varying the anions, where the luminescent properties of these complexes have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text: Thirteen Cd(II)-containing coordination polymers based on a novel tetradentate ligand tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L) have been successfully synthesized by varying the anions, where the luminescent properties of these complexes have also been investigated.

elements.content: Coordination polymers are currently of great interest due to their potential applications in ion exchange, gas storage, optics, magnetism, and catalysis as well as their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. So far, a number of N-donor bridging ligands such as pyrazine, 4,4′-bipyridine, 1,2-bis(4′-pyridyl)ethane/ethene, and 1,3-bis(4′-pyridyl)-propane have been widely employed to construct coordination polymers with fascinating architectures and interesting properties. Among the N-donor bridging ligands, flexible multidentate ligands with imidazole groups have attracted great interest. According to the differences of the spacers, the reported imidazole-containing ligands can be classified into two types: one contains the aryl spacers, such as 1,2-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1-(1-imidazolyl)-3,5-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, and hexakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, while the other contains the alkyl spacers, such as 1,1′-(methanediyl)bis(imidazole), 1,1′-(1,2-ethanediyl)bis(imidazole), 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole), 1,1′-(1,5-pentanedidyl)bis(imidazole), and 1,1′-(1,6-hexanediyl)bis(imidazole). Up to now, the aryl substituted bis(imidazole) and tris(imidazole) ligands have already been widely reported, whereas only a few coordination polymers based on the aryl substituted tetrakis(imidazole) or hexakis(imidazole) ligands have been observed. However, the study for coordination polymers containing the alkyl substituted polyimidazole ligands are mainly focused on the bis(imidazole) ligands. To the best of our knowledge, the coordination chemistry of the alkyl substituted tetrakis(imidazole) ligand has never been investigated. The tetrakis(imidazol) ligand tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L) (Scheme ) which is the first alkyl substituted tetrakis(imidazole) ligand is expected to be a good candidate for construction of coordination polymers with diverse structures. First, four imidazole N atoms of the L ligand can act as four potential coordination nodes. Second, the four imidazole groups can freely twist around the quaternary carbon atom (Ccenter) and four -CH2- groups with different bond angles to meet the requirements of the coordination geometries.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers are currently of great interest due to their potential applications in ion exchange, gas storage, optics, magnetism, and catalysis as well as their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. So far, a number of N-donor bridging ligands such as pyrazine, 4,4'-bipyridine, 1,2-bis(4'-pyridyl)ethane/ethene, and 1,3-bis(4'-pyridyl)-propane have been widely employed to construct coordination polymers with fascinating architectures and interesting properties. Among the N-donor bridging ligands, flexible multidentate ligands with imidazole groups have attracted great interest. According to the differences of the spacers, the reported imidazole-containing ligands can be classified into two types: one contains the aryl spacers, such as 1,2-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1-(1-imidazolyl)-3,5-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, and hexakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, while the other contains the alkyl spacers, such as 1,1'-(methanediyl)bis(imidazole), 1,1'-(1,2-ethanediyl)bis(imidazole), 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole), 1,1'-(1,5-pentanedidyl)bis(imidazole), and 1,1'-(1,6-hexanediyl)bis(imidazole). Up to now, the aryl substituted bis(imidazole) and tris(imidazole) ligands have already been widely reported, whereas only a few coordination polymers based on the aryl substituted tetrakis(imidazole) or hexakis(imidazole) ligands have been observed.   However, the study for coordination polymers containing the alkyl substituted polyimidazole ligands are mainly focused on the bis(imidazole) ligands. To the best of our knowledge, the coordination chemistry of the alkyl substituted tetrakis(imidazole) ligand has never been investigated. The tetrakis(imidazol) ligand tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L) (Scheme ) which is the first alkyl substituted tetrakis(imidazole) ligand is expected to be a good candidate for construction of coordination polymers with diverse structures. First, four imidazole N atoms of the L ligand can act as four potential coordination nodes. Second, the four imidazole groups can freely twist around the quaternary carbon atom (Ccenter) and four -CH2- groups with different bond angles to meet the requirements of the coordination geometries.

elements.content: On the other hand, the anions play an important role in the construction of coordination polymers with distinctive structures, but systematic investigations on the influence of the inorganic and organic anions on the complex structures have been lacking. In order to investigate the effect of anions on the complex structures based on this novel tetrakis(imidazole) ligand, three inorganic anions (NO3 −, Br−, SO4 2−) and 10 organic polycarboxylates were used and a remarkable class of Cd(II)-containing coordination polymers were successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions: [Cd2(L)2(SO4)2(H2O)2]·4H2O (1), [Cd(L)(H2O)2](NO3)2 (2), [Cd(L)(Br)2]·H2O (3), [Cd(L)0.5(L1)] (4), [Cd5(L2)5(H2O)2]·6H2O (5), [CdL3(L)0.5] (6), [CdL4(L)0.5(H2O)]·H2O (7), [Cd2(L5)2(L)]·2H2O (8), [Cd3(L6)2(L)]·4H2O (9), Cd3(L7)2(L)(H2O)2]·2.5H2O (10), [Cd(HL8)(L)]·0.75H2O (11), [Cd7(L9)3(μ3-OH)2(L)2]·8H2O (12), [Cd2(L10)(L)(H2O)2]·H2O (13), where H2L1 = fumaric acid, H2L2 = adipic acid, H2L3 = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2L4 = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2L5 = 5-OH-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H3L6 = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H3L7 = 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H3L8 = 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H4L9 = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid, and H4L10 = 4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid. The structures and topological analyses of these compounds, along with the influence of the anions on the structures of the coordination polymers and the coordination modes of tetrakis(imidazole) ligands, will be represented and discussed. The photoluminescent properties of these compounds have also been investigated.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. The pentaerythrityl tetratosylate was synthesized by following the procedures described previously.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. The pentaerythrityl tetratosylate was synthesized by following the procedures described previously.

elements.content: A mixture of imidazole (2.7 g, 40 mmol) and NaOH (1.6 g, 40 mmol) in DMSO (5 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and then pentaerythrityl tetratosylate (7.8 g, 10 mmol) was added. The DMSO were evaporated to dry after the mixture was stirred at 100 °C for 24 h. Twenty-five milliliters ethanol was added to the resulting mixture and filtrated. Then 100 mL of acetic ether was added to the filtrate, and a white solid L was obtained. Then colorless crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were grown by recrystallization from ethanol−water (yield: 86%). Anal. Calcd for C17H30N8O5 (M r = 426.49): C, 47.88; H, 7.09; N, 26.27. Found: C, 47.62; H, 7.21; N, 26.41. IR (cm−1): 3468(s), 3150(w), 1655(s), 1501(s), 1447(m), 1428(w), 1407(w), 1368(w), 1386(m), 1235(s), 1097(s), 1072(w), 1028(m), 915(m), 845(m), 763(m), 730(w), 659(m), 628(m), 537(w).

Synthesis of Tetrakis(Imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane⋅5H2O (L⋅5H2O)

A mixture of imidazole (2.7 g, 40 mmol) and NaOH (1.6 g, 40 mmol) in DMSO (5 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and then pentaerythrityl tetratosylate (7.8 g, 10 mmol) was added. The DMSO were evaporated to dry after the mixture was stirred at 100 °C for 24 h. Twenty-five milliliters ethanol was added to the resulting mixture and filtrated. Then 100 mL of acetic ether was added to the filtrate, and a white solid L was obtained. Then colorless crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were grown by recrystallization from ethanol-water (yield: 86%). Anal. Calcd for C17H30N8O5 (M r = 426.49): C, 47.88; H, 7.09; N, 26.27. Found: C, 47.62; H, 7.21; N, 26.41. IR (cm-1): 3468(s), 3150(w), 1655(s), 1501(s), 1447(m), 1428(w), 1407(w), 1368(w), 1386(m), 1235(s), 1097(s), 1072(w), 1028(m), 915(m), 845(m), 763(m), 730(w), 659(m), 628(m), 537(w).

elements.content: The C, H, and N elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm−1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. The photoluminescent properties of the ligands and compounds were measured on a Perkin-Elmer FLS-920 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 40 to 800 °C under nitrogen. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 5 to 40°. The experimental powder XRD patterns are in good agreement with the corresponding simulated ones (Figures S5−S7 in the ) except for the relative intensity variation because of preferred orientations of the crystals. Therefore, the phase purity of the as-synthesized products is substantiated.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

The C, H, and N elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. The photoluminescent properties of the ligands and compounds were measured on a Perkin-Elmer FLS-920 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 40 to 800 °C under nitrogen. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 5 to 40°. The experimental powder XRD patterns are in good agreement with the corresponding simulated ones (Figures S5-S7 in the ) except for the relative intensity variation because of preferred orientations of the crystals. Therefore, the phase purity of the as-synthesized products is substantiated.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for L·5H2O and 1−13 was recorded on a Oxford Diffraction Gemini R Ultra diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using a multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbons were generated geometrically. Some aqua hydrogen atoms of compounds 3, 9, 10, and 13 were not included in the model. Other hydrogen atoms of water molecules and hydroxyl hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Non-hydrogen atoms of the complexes were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters except that O1W and O1W′ for 13 were refined with isotropic temperature parameters. O5, O7, and O8 for 1, O1W for 3, C5 to C8, O3 and O4 for 4, C6 to C9, C32, and C33 for 8, C1, C6, C8, C9, N1 to N4, O6, and O1W for 9, O1W for 13 are disordered. The disordered atoms were refined using isotropic C, O, and N atoms split over two sites, with a total occupancy of 1. The hydrogen atoms of the disordered C atoms were not included in the model. All H atoms bound to carbon were refined using a riding model with d(C−H) = 0.93 Å, U iso = 1.2U eq(C) for aromatic and 0.97 Å, U iso =1.5U eq(C) for CH2 atoms. Water H atoms and hydroxyl H atoms were located in a difference Fourier map and refined as riding atoms with d(O−H) = 0.85−0.89 Å and U iso = 1.5U eq(O). The C(sp3)−C(sp3), and C(sp3)−N bond lengths were restrained to 1.50−1.53 Å, and C(sp2)−C(sp2) were restrained to 1.35 Å in compounds 4 and 8.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for L⋅5H2O and 1-13 was recorded on a Oxford Diffraction Gemini R Ultra diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using a multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbons were generated geometrically. Some aqua hydrogen atoms of compounds 3, 9, 10, and 13 were not included in the model. Other hydrogen atoms of water molecules and hydroxyl hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Non-hydrogen atoms of the complexes were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters except that O1W and O1W' for 13 were refined with isotropic temperature parameters. O5, O7, and O8 for 1, O1W for 3, C5 to C8, O3 and O4 for 4, C6 to C9, C32, and C33 for 8, C1, C6, C8, C9, N1 to N4, O6, and O1W for 9, O1W for 13 are disordered. The disordered atoms were refined using isotropic C, O, and N atoms split over two sites, with a total occupancy of 1. The hydrogen atoms of the disordered C atoms were not included in the model. All H atoms bound to carbon were refined using a riding model with d(C-H) = 0.93 Å, U iso = 1.2U eq(C) for aromatic and 0.97 Å, U iso =1.5U eq(C) for CH2 atoms. Water H atoms and hydroxyl H atoms were located in a difference Fourier map and refined as riding atoms with d(O-H) = 0.85-0.89 Å and U iso = 1.5U eq(O). The C(sp3)-C(sp3), and C(sp3)-N bond lengths were restrained to 1.50-1.53 Å, and C(sp2)-C(sp2) were restrained to 1.35 Å in compounds 4 and 8.

As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of L·5H2O consists of one L molecule and five water molecules. In this structure, the water molecules and their symmetry-related molecules link to each other to form a cyclic (H2O)10 cluster through hydrogen bonds (Figure b). Within (H2O)10 cluster, O1W and O1W#3 act as hydrogen-bond acceptors, while O3W and O3W#3 act as hydrogen-bond donors. However, O2W, O2W#3, O4W, O4W#3, O5W, and O5W#3 serve as both donors and acceptors. Interestingly, the cyclic (H2O)10 clusters are further linked to a 1D infinite water chain through the O4W−H4C···O3W#3 and O4W#3−H4C#3···O3W hydrogen bonds (Figure c). This water motif can be classified as T4(2)10(2) tape. So far, water clusters and tapes have been extensively studied both theoretically and experimentally. However, the T4(2)10(2) tape is rarely observed in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure of L⋅5H2O

As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of L⋅5H2O consists of one L molecule and five water molecules. In this structure, the water molecules and their symmetry-related molecules link to each other to form a cyclic (H2O)10 cluster through hydrogen bonds (Figure b). Within (H2O)10 cluster, O1W and O1W#3 act as hydrogen-bond acceptors, while O3W and O3W#3 act as hydrogen-bond donors. However, O2W, O2W#3, O4W, O4W#3, O5W, and O5W#3 serve as both donors and acceptors. Interestingly, the cyclic (H2O)10 clusters are further linked to a 1D infinite water chain through the O4W-H4C⋅⋅⋅O3W#3 and O4W#3-H4C#3⋅⋅⋅O3W hydrogen bonds (Figure c). This water motif can be classified as T4(2)10(2) tape. So far, water clusters and tapes have been extensively studied both theoretically and experimentally. However, the T4(2)10(2) tape is rarely observed in the literature.

elements.content: Moreover, the nitrogen atoms from the free L ligand form hydrogen bonds with the water molecules (O1W−H1D···N4#1, O1W−H1C···N8, O2W−H2C···N6), leading to a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure d). In this complex, every (H2O)10 cluster is connected to six L ligands and two adjacent (H2O)10 clusters through hydrogen bonds. Thus, the (H2O)10 cluster can be viewed as an eight-connected node. Additionally, each L ligand is linked by three (H2O)10 clusters as a three-connected node, and therefore, the 3D framework can be simplified as a binodal (3,8)-connected hydrogen-bonded network with a (3·52)2(34·42·56·612·73·8) topology (Figure e). So far, there are several reports of the (3,8)-connected nets, but the topological structure of L·5H2O is unique and unprecedented. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first (3,8)-connected net constructed through hydrogen-bond interactions.

Additionally, each L ligand is linked by three (H2O)10 clusters as a three-connected node, and therefore, the 3D framework can be simplified as a binodal (3,8)-connected hydrogen-bonded network with a (3⋅52)2(34⋅42⋅56⋅612⋅73⋅8) topology (Figure e). So far, there are several reports of the (3,8)-connected nets, but the topological structure of L⋅5H2O is unique and unprecedented. elements.content: To investigate the influence of inorganic ions on the complex framework, CdSO4·8/3H2O, Cd(NO3)2·4H2O, and CdBr2·4H2O were used to react with tetrakis(imidazole) under the same synthetic conditions. The L reacted with CdSO4·8/3H2O under hydrothermal conditions to give complex 1. The X-ray crystallographic study shows that there are two crystallographically independent Cd(II) centers with different coordination environments, two kinds of crystallographically independent ligands L, two coordinated sulfate anions, two coordinated water molecules, and four lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit of 1. The Cd1 is six-coordinated by four imidazole N atoms from four independent ligands L in the equatorial positions and two water molecules in the apical positions showing an octahedral coordination geometry. The Cd−N bond distances are in the range of 2.330(2)−2.404(2) Å and the Cd−O bond lengths are 2.287(2) and 2.316(2) Å, respectively. Cd2 shows a coordination environment similar to that of Cd1 except that the two coordinated water molecules are replaced by two sulfate anions in the apical positions with the Cd−N bond distances in the range of 2.323(2)−2.344(2) Å and the Cd−O bond lengths of 2.314(2) and 2.364(4) Å (Figure a). Each sulfate anion serves as a monodentate ligand to coordinate to the Cd2 atoms. In addition, each ligand L also acts as a tetradentate ligand binding with two Cd1 and two Cd2 atoms in mode I (Scheme ) to form a 3D structure (Figure b). Better insight into the present 3D frameworks can be accessed by the topological method. If Cd(II) atoms and L ligands can be defined as 4-connecting nodes, the 3D structure of 1 can be described as a 4-connected PtS network (Figure c).

The L reacted with CdSO4⋅8/3H2O under hydrothermal conditions to give complex 1. The Cd1 is six-coordinated by four imidazole N atoms from four independent ligands L in the equatorial positions and two water molecules in the apical positions showing an octahedral coordination geometry. The Cd-N bond distances are in the range of 2.330(2)-2.404(2) Å and the Cd-O bond lengths are 2.287(2) and 2.316(2) Å, respectively. Cd2 shows a coordination environment similar to that of Cd1 except that the two coordinated water molecules are replaced by two sulfate anions in the apical positions with the Cd-N bond distances in the range of 2.323(2)-2.344(2) Å and the Cd-O bond lengths of 2.314(2) and 2.364(4) Å (Figure a). Each sulfate anion serves as a monodentate ligand to coordinate to the Cd2 atoms. elements.content: When CdSO4·8/3H2O was replaced by Cd(NO3)2·4H2O, a structurally different complex 2 was obtained. As shown in Figure a, the structure of 2 consists of one crystallographically independent Cd(II) ion, one L ligand, two coordinated water molecules, and two uncoordinated nitrate ions. The Cd(II) ion is in an octahedral CdN4O2 coordination geometry, coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four L ligands (Cd−N 2.294(2)−2.354(2) Å) in the equatorial positions and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules (Cd−O 2.321(2)−2.354(2) Å) in the apical positions. Like that in 1, each ligand L connects four Cd(II) atoms in a tetradentate mode (mode I) to form a 3D framework structure as illustrated in Figure b. Topologically, Cd(II) atoms and L ligands can be reduced to 4-connected nodes, respectively; thus the 3D structure of 2 can be described as a 4-connected zeolite ABW net (also named as sra) with the vertex symbol (42·63·8) (Figure c). In the case of 4-connected nets with tetrahedral nodes, the dia (diamond) net has been reported widely, while the sra net is relatively rare. The framework is positively charged and the channels are filled with uncoordinated nitrate ions which are interconnected with the coordinated water molecules through hydrogen bonds (O1W−H1C···O1, O1W−H1D···O4#5, O2W−H2D···O2#4, O2W−H2D···O1#4, O2W−H2C···O5#6).

Structure of [Cd(L)(H2O)2](NO3)2 (2)

When CdSO4⋅8/3H2O was replaced by Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O, a structurally different complex 2 was obtained. As shown in Figure a, the structure of 2 consists of one crystallographically independent Cd(II) ion, one L ligand, two coordinated water molecules, and two uncoordinated nitrate ions. The Cd(II) ion is in an octahedral CdN4O2 coordination geometry, coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four L ligands (Cd-N 2.294(2)-2.354(2) Å) in the equatorial positions and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules (Cd-O 2.321(2)-2.354(2) Å) in the apical positions. Like that in 1, each ligand L connects four Cd(II) atoms in a tetradentate mode (mode I) to form a 3D framework structure as illustrated in Figure b. Topologically, Cd(II) atoms and L ligands can be reduced to 4-connected nodes, respectively; thus the 3D structure of 2 can be described as a 4-connected zeolite ABW net (also named as sra) with the vertex symbol (42⋅63⋅8) (Figure c). In the case of 4-connected nets with tetrahedral nodes, the dia (diamond) net has been reported widely, while the sra net is relatively rare. The framework is positively charged and the channels are filled with uncoordinated nitrate ions which are interconnected with the coordinated water molecules through hydrogen bonds (O1W-H1C⋅⋅⋅O1, O1W-H1D⋅⋅⋅O4#5, O2W-H2D⋅⋅⋅O2#4, O2W-H2D⋅⋅⋅O1#4, O2W-H2C⋅⋅⋅O5#6).

elements.content: When CdSO4·8/3H2O was replaced by CdBr2·4H2O, a 2D complex 3 was obtained. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains one crystallographically independent Cd(II) ion, one L ligand, two coordinated bromide anions, and one lattice water molecule. As shown in Figure a, each Cd(II) atom is coordinated with four individual ligands L via nitrogen atoms (Cd−N 2.340(5)−2.407(6) Å), and two bromide anions (Cd−Br 2.788(1)−2.737(1) Å), exhibiting a distorted CdN4Br2 octahedral coordination geometry. The coordination environment of Cd(II) atom is similar to that in complex 2 except that the two coordinated water molecules are replaced by two bromide anions in the apical positions. Cd(II) atoms are linked by L ligand to form a 2D layer structure (Figure b). From a topological perspective, the Cd(II) atoms and L ligands can be viewed as 4-connected nodes, and this 2D layer can be described as a (44)-sql net.

elements.content: Because the anions play a crucial role in determining the molecular structures of the resultant complexes, organic carboxylate ligands were used instead of the inorganic ions for better understanding the effect of the anions on the structures of the complexes. To examine the influence of organic acid spacer on the complex framework, five kinds of dicarboxylate ligands H2L1, H2L2, H2L3, H2L4, and H2L5 were used to react with CdCO3 and the L ligand under similar reaction conditions, and five new compounds [Cd(L)0.5(L1)] (4), [Cd5(L2)5(H2O)2]·6H2O (5), [CdL3(L)0.5] (6), [CdL4(L)0.5(H2O)]·H2O (7), and [Cd2(L5)2(L)]·2H2O (8) were obtained.

Structure of [Cd(L)0.5(L1)] (4)

Because the anions play a crucial role in determining the molecular structures of the resultant complexes, organic carboxylate ligands were used instead of the inorganic ions for better understanding the effect of the anions on the structures of the complexes. To examine the influence of organic acid spacer on the complex framework, five kinds of dicarboxylate ligands H2L1, H2L2, H2L3, H2L4, and H2L5 were used to react with CdCO3 and the L ligand under similar reaction conditions, and five new compounds [Cd(L)0.5(L1)] (4), [Cd5(L2)5(H2O)2]⋅6H2O (5), [CdL3(L)0.5] (6), [CdL4(L)0.5(H2O)]⋅H2O (7), and [Cd2(L5)2(L)]⋅2H2O (8) were obtained.

elements.content: In 4, there exist one Cd(II) ion, one L1 ligand on a 2-fold axis, and a quarter of L ligand in the crystallographically independent unit (Figure a). Cd1 cation lies at an inversion center and is seven-coordinated by five oxygen atoms from three L1 ligands (Cd−O 2.318(19)−2.56(2) Å) and two nitrogen atoms (Cd−N 2.270(6) Å) from two L ligands in a pentagonal bipyramidal environment. The carboxylate groups of L1 connect two Cd(II) atoms to form a double-core subunit with a Cd···Cd distance of 4.147 Å. Each double-core subunit is linked by four L1 ligands to construct a 2D layer (Figure b). Each L ligand coordinates to four Cd(II) centers (mode III), leading the 2D layer to form a 3D polymeric network (Figure c). If the double-core subunits are considered as four-connected nodes, and the L and L1 are considered as two kinds of connectors, this structure can be regarded as an α-Po topology. The two identical α-Po nets are further interpenetrated in 2-fold mode (Figure d).

elements.content: When H2L1 was replaced by H2L2, a structurally different compound 5 was obtained. As shown in Figure a, complex 5 contains three kinds of Cd(II) atoms, one kind of L ligand, and three kinds of L2 anions (L2A, L2B, L2C). The three kinds of Cd(II) ions exhibit coordination numbers of 5, 6, and 7, respectively. Cd1 is located at an inversion center, while Cd2 and Cd3 lie in general positions. Cd1 is six-coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L2A and two L2B exhibiting a distorted octahedral coordination environment. Cd2 is five-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three L ligands, and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L2A in a distorted tetragonal pyramidal geometry. Cd3 is seven-coordinated by one nitrogen atoms from the L ligand, and six carboxylate oxygen atoms from one L2A and two L2B anions exhibiting a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. Each carboxylate group of L2A links to two Cd atoms, while those of L2B and L2C anion coordinate to one Cd atom in the bis-chelating mode. One Cd1, two symmetry-related Cd2, and two symmetry-related Cd3 atoms are connected by μ2-Ocarboxyl bridge to form a pentanuclear Cd(II) unit (Figure b), which is further linked by the L2 ligands to generate a 3D framework (Figure c). Each L ligand, acting as a tetradentate ligand, links the Cd2 and Cd3 atoms (mode II) to produce a 2D layer (Figure e) which further stabilized the 3D framework (Figure f). Moreover, there exist some hydrogen bonds in the 3D structure of 5 (O1W−H1C···O3W#5, O1W−H1D···O10#4, O2W−H2C···O4#9, O2W−H2D···O3#5, O3W−H3C···O5, O3W−H3D···O2W).

elements.content: When H2L1 was replaced by H2L3, a new compound 6 was obtained. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 6 consists of one crystallographically independent Cd(II) ion, one L3 anion, and half of L ligand. The Cd(II) ion is six-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three L3 anions (Cd1−O1 = 2.338(3), Cd1−O2 = 2.549(1), Cd1−O3#2 = 2.334(1) and Cd1−O4#3 = 2.385(2) Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands (Cd1−N4 = 2.273(2) and Cd1−N1#1 = 2.264(2) Å) exhibiting a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The μ2-O4 links two Cd(II) atoms to afford a binuclear Cd(II) unit. The binuclear units are bridged by L3 ligands to give rise to an one-dimensional (1D) double chain (Figure b) which span two directions to give rise to a plywood-like packing mode (Figure c). In addition, the L ligands further connect such chains (mode III) to yield a 3D framework. Better insight into the present 3D frameworks can be accessed by the topological method. Binuclear Cd(II) clusters can be considered as 4-connected nodes; meanwhile the L and L3 ligands can be viewed as linkers, so the topology of net for 6 can be best described as a 3D (65·8) CdSO4-type framework (Figure d).

elements.content: When H2L1 was replaced by H2L4, a completely different compound 7 was obtained. As illustrated in Figure a, the structure of 7 contains one Cd(II) atom, two halves of two unique L4 anions, half of L ligand, one coordinated water molecule, and one lattice water molecule. The Cd(II) atom is six-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two L4 ligands, two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands, and one water molecule in a distorted octahedral environment (Cd−O 2.302(3)−2.568(4) Å, Cd−N 2.293(4)−2.337(4) Å). In addition, one carboxylate oxygen atom O1 weakly coordinate to the Cd1 cation with a distance of 2.687(5) Å. Each L ligand coordinates to four Cd atoms acting as a tetradentate ligand (mode I). The two kinds of L4 anions serve as bridges linking adjacent Cd centers into 1D zigzag chains with two different Cd···Cd distances (Cd···Cd = 11.411(4) and 11.351(2) Å) (Figure b). The chains are further linked by the L ligand via Cd−N to form a 3D structure (Figure c). From the topological view, if the Cd(II) center and the L ligand can be considered as two 4-connected nodes, and L4 ligand as a linker, the framework of 7 becomes a 4-connected binodal net with Schläfli symbol of (4·62·72·8)(42·62·7·8) (Figure d). In addition, the 3D structure of 7 is further stabilized by hydrogen-bonding interactions (O1W−H1C···O1#5, O1W−H1D···O3#5, O2W−H2C···O1#6).

elements.content: When H2L3 was replaced with H2L5, a 2D structure of compound 8 was obtained. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 8 contains two crystallographically independent Cd(II) atoms, two kinds of L5 anions (L5A, L5B), one kind of L ligand, and two lattice water molecules. The two unique Cd atoms exhibit two different coordination geometries. Cd1 is six-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd−O 2.297(3)−2.467(3) Å) from three L5A anions, and two nitrogen atoms (Cd−N 2.271(3)−2.270(3) Å) from two L ligands in a distorted octahedral environment. Cd2 is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd−O 2.244(3)−2.448(3) Å) from two L5B anions, and two nitrogen atoms (Cd−N 2.220(3)−2.284(11) Å) from two L ligands in a distorted tetragonal pyramidal geometry. In addition, O7 is weakly coordinated to Cd2 with a distance of 2.650(4) Å. L5A anions link the Cd1 atoms to form a ladder-like chain (Figure b), while L5B anions link the Cd2 atoms to yield a single chain along the b axis (Figure c). If L5 ligands are neglected, the L ligands connect the Cd(II) atoms (mode II) to generate 1D ladder-like chains (Figure d), which are further bridged by two kinds of L5 anions to form a 2D network (Figure e). From the topological view, the two adjacent Cd1 atoms and the L can be viewed as two kinds of 4-connected nodes, and the Cd2 can be viewed as a 3-connected node. Meanwhile, the L5 ligands can be considered as linkers, so the structure of 8 can be described as a (3,4)-connected 2D network with a (63)2(64·8·10)(64·82)2 topology (). In addition, the extra hydroxyl groups in L5 and the lattice water molecules donate hydrogen bonds to carboxylate O atoms (O1W−H1C···O6; O2W−H2C···O4; O10−H10A···O7; O1W−H1D···O5#8), which further extend the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular network ().

elements.content: To study the influence of the carboxylate positions on their complex structures, three tricarboxylate ligands containing phenyl groups H3L6, H3L7, and H3L8 were selected to react with CdCO3 under similar synthetic conditions, and three new complexes [Cd3(L6)2(L)]·4H2O (9), [Cd3(L7)2(L)(H2O)2]·2.5H2O (10), and [Cd(HL8)(L)]·0.75H2O (11) were obtained.

Structure of [Cd3(L6)2(L)]⋅4H2O (9)

To study the influence of the carboxylate positions on their complex structures, three tricarboxylate ligands containing phenyl groups H3L6, H3L7, and H3L8 were selected to react with CdCO3 under similar synthetic conditions, and three new complexes [Cd3(L6)2(L)]⋅4H2O (9), [Cd3(L7)2(L)(H2O)2]⋅2.5H2O (10), and [Cd(HL8)(L)]⋅0.75H2O (11) were obtained.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 9 contains two kinds of unique Cd atoms, one kinds of L ligand, one kind of unique L6 anions ligands, and four lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure a, Cd1, which is located at an inversion center, is six-coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms from four L6 anions (Cd−O 2.298(3)−2.390(3) Å) in a distorted octahedral environment. Cd2 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands (Cd−N 2.134(17)−2.300(13) Å) and four carboxylate oxygen atoms from the L6 (Cd2−O 2.308(3)−2.545(2) Å) in an octahedral geometry. Each L6 coordinates to five Cd atoms in a pentadentate mode, forming a 2D wavelike layer with interlayer distance of 12.91 Å (Figure b). Each L ligand coordinates to four Cd2 ions (mode II) to generate a 2D layer along the c axis (Figure c). The two kinds of layers are almost vertical to each other, which are further linked by Cd atoms to generate a complicated 3D structure (Figure d).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis revealed that 10 crystallized in a chiral monoclinic space group C2. The structure of 10 consists of two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions, one kind of L7 anion, and one kind of L ligand. As shown in Figure a, the Cd1 ion, lying on independent inversion center, is six-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L7 anions and two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands (Cd−O 2.219(5)−2.392(6) Å, Cd−N = 2.249(6) Å), showing an octahedral geometry. Cd2 ion is seven-coordinated by five oxygen atoms from five L7 anions, one water molecule, and one nitrogen atom from one L ligand (Cd−O 2.309(7)−O 2.495(6) Å, Cd−N = 2.327(6) Å) exhibiting a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. The carboxylate oxygen atoms of L7 ligands bridge one Cd1 and two Cd2 ions to generate a trinuclear Cd(II) cluster (Figure b). If the L ligands are neglected, L7 ligands bridge the trinuclear Cd(II) clusters to generate a 2D layer (Figure c). The L ligands coordinate to two kinds of Cd(II) atoms (mode III), linking the 2D layers into a 3D framework (Figure d). From the topological view, if the trinuclear Cd(II) clusters can be viewed as 4-connected nodes and the L and L7 ligands can be viewed as linkers, the structure of 10 can be simplified to an α-Po net (Figure e). In addition, there exist some hydrogen bonds (O1W−H1C···O1W#1, O1W−H1D···O2W#2, O2W−H2C···O3#5, O2W−H2C···O1#5, O2W−H2D···O4), which consolidate the network of 10. So far, chiral coordination polymers based upon chiral ligand have been extensively reported; however, the ones constructed by achiral ligands are scarcely observed.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 11 consists of one crystallographically independent Cd(II) ion, one kind of HL8 anion, one kind of L ligand, and three-quarters of lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure a, the Cd1 ion is six-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two HL8 anions and four nitrogen atoms from four L ligands (Cd−O 2.219(5)−2.392(6) Å, Cd−N = 2.249(6) Å) in a distorted octahedral environment. N4#1 and N1 are in the apical positions, and the O1, O2, N6#8, and N8#3 are in the equatorial positions. For the HL8 ligand, only two of the carboxyl groups are deprotonated. Interestingly, only one deprotonated carboxyl group (containing O1 and O2) coordinates to the Cd(II) ion in chelating fashion, whereas the other deprotonated carboxyl group is free. The L coordinates to the Cd(II) center as a tetradentate ligand (mode I), generating a 2D layer parallel to the ab plane (Figure b). Better insight into such an intricate framework can be accessed by reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-connecting nets. Each L anion connects to four Cd atoms, and each Cd center is linked by four L ligands. So the 2D framework of 11 can be simplified to a uninodal 4-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (42·64) (Figure c). Also, the hydrogen bond between the lattice water molecule O1W and carboxylate O1 stabilizes the framework.

elements.content: The tetracarboxylate ligands H4L9 and H4L10 reacted with the Cd(II) atoms in the presence of the L ligand to give compounds [Cd7(L9)3(μ3-OH)2(L)2]·8H2O (12) and [Cd2(L10)(L)(H2O)2]·H2O (13), respectively. As illustrated in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 12 consists of four kinds of Cd(II) atoms, one of which, Cd1, lies on an inversion center, two kinds of L9 anions (L9A lies on an inversion center, while L9B lies in a general position), one L ligand, one μ3-OH and four water molecules. Cd1 is six-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from two L9A, two L9B, and two μ3-OH with Cd−O distances of 2.273(3)−2.363 Å in a distorted octahedral environment. Cd2 is five-coordinated by one nitrogen atom from L ligand (Cd−N = 2.314(4) Å), four oxygen atoms from two L9A, one L9B, and one μ3-OH (Cd−O 2.194(3)−2.317(3) Å) in a distorted tetragonal pyramidal geometry. Cd3 is seven-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands (Cd−N 2.227(3)−2.284(4) Å), and five oxygen atoms from three L9A (Cd−O 2.333(3)−2.579(3) Å) exhibiting a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. Cd4 is six-coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one L ligand (Cd−N = 2.300(4) Å), five oxygen atoms from one L9A, two L9B and one μ3-OH (Cd−O 2.200(3)−2.381(3) Å) showing a distorted octahedral environment. Each L9A anion coordinates to seven Cd(II) cations (one Cd1, two Cd2, three Cd3, and one Cd4) to form a 2D sheet parallel to the ac plane (Figure b), whereas each L9B coordinates to 10 Cd(II) cations (two symmetry-related Cd1, four symmetry-related Cd2, and four symmetry-related Cd4) to form a 2D sheet parallel to the ab plane (Figure c). The two kinds of sheets are linked by carboxylate groups of L9 anions and μ3-OH to generate a Cd-L9 3D framework (Figure d). Two L ligands coordinate to Cd(II) (mode II) via Cd−N bonds to form a dimer. The dimers are linked by the μ3-OH and Cd1 to form a layer parallel to the bc plane (Figure e), which further stabilizes the 3D structure (Figure f). Moreover, there exist hydrogen bonds among the lattice water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1W−H1D···O10, O2W−H2C···O3, O2W−H2D···O4W, O3W−H3D···O3, O4W−H4C···O2, O4W−H4D···O3W), which stabilize the structure.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Cd7(L9)3(μ3-OH)2(L)2]⋅8H2O (12)

The tetracarboxylate ligands H4L9 and H4L10 reacted with the Cd(II) atoms in the presence of the L ligand to give compounds [Cd7(L9)3(μ3-OH)2(L)2]⋅8H2O (12) and [Cd2(L10)(L)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (13), respectively. As illustrated in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 12 consists of four kinds of Cd(II) atoms, one of which, Cd1, lies on an inversion center, two kinds of L9 anions (L9A lies on an inversion center, while L9B lies in a general position), one L ligand, one μ3-OH and four water molecules. Cd1 is six-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from two L9A, two L9B, and two μ3-OH with Cd-O distances of 2.273(3)-2.363 Å in a distorted octahedral environment. Cd2 is five-coordinated by one nitrogen atom from L ligand (Cd-N = 2.314(4) Å), four oxygen atoms from two L9A, one L9B, and one μ3-OH (Cd-O 2.194(3)-2.317(3) Å) in a distorted tetragonal pyramidal geometry. Cd3 is seven-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands (Cd-N 2.227(3)-2.284(4) Å), and five oxygen atoms from three L9A (Cd-O 2.333(3)-2.579(3) Å) exhibiting a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. Cd4 is six-coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one L ligand (Cd-N = 2.300(4) Å), five oxygen atoms from one L9A, two L9B and one μ3-OH (Cd-O 2.200(3)-2.381(3) Å) showing a distorted octahedral environment. Each L9A anion coordinates to seven Cd(II) cations (one Cd1, two Cd2, three Cd3, and one Cd4) to form a 2D sheet parallel to the ac plane (Figure b), whereas each L9B coordinates to 10 Cd(II) cations (two symmetry-related Cd1, four symmetry-related Cd2, and four symmetry-related Cd4) to form a 2D sheet parallel to the ab plane (Figure c). The two kinds of sheets are linked by carboxylate groups of L9 anions and μ3-OH to generate a Cd-L9 3D framework (Figure d). Two L ligands coordinate to Cd(II) (mode II) via Cd-N bonds to form a dimer. The dimers are linked by the μ3-OH and Cd1 to form a layer parallel to the bc plane (Figure e), which further stabilizes the 3D structure (Figure f). Moreover, there exist hydrogen bonds among the lattice water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1W-H1D⋅⋅⋅O10, O2W-H2C⋅⋅⋅O3, O2W-H2D⋅⋅⋅O4W, O3W-H3D⋅⋅⋅O3, O4W-H4C⋅⋅⋅O2, O4W-H4D⋅⋅⋅O3W), which stabilize the structure.

elements.content: When H2L1 was replaced by H4L10, a new compound 13 was obtained. X-ray analyses reveal that the asymmetric unit of compound 13 contains two kinds of Cd(II) cations, one kind of L10 ligands, and one kind of L ligand (Figure a). Cd1 shows an octahedral geometry and is six-coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L10 ligands, two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands with N2−Cd1−N7#1 = 88.37(7)°, and one water molecule. Cd2 is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands with N6#4−Cd2−N4#5 = 144.40(7)°, three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L10 ligands, and one water molecule. Each L ligand coordinates to two symmetry-related Cd1 and two symmetry-related Cd2 (mode I) to form a 1D chain (Figure b), and each L10 ligand coordinates to two symmetry-related Cd1 and two symmetry-related Cd2 to generate a 2D layer (Figure c). The layers and the chains are further linked by Cd atoms to form a 3D framework (Figure d). If Cd1, Cd2, L ligands and L10 anions are considered as four kinds of four-connected nodes, the structure of 13 can be symbolized as a 4-connected net with a (63·83)(4·85)(4·6·84)(6·85) topology (Figure e). In addition, the water molecules donate hydrogen bonds to carboxylate oxygen atoms (O11−H11C···O6#9, O11−H11D···O7#3), consolidating the 3D framework.

elements.content: From the structure description above, we can see that the tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L) ligands can bend and rotate freely when coordinating to the central metals due to the flexible nature of the spacers between the four imidazole rings. Though the L ligands act as tetradentate ligands in the compounds 1−13, they display three kinds of different coordination modes (Scheme ). The difference of the coordination modes can be attributed to the discrimination of the Cd−Ccenter−Cd angles (θ) (Scheme ). There are six Cd−Ccenter−Cd angles (θ) among any two Cd(II) atoms and the center carbon atom of L (Ccenter) (Table ). From the angles of the Table and the structures of compounds 1−13, we can see that when all of the six θ angles are greater than 40°, the L ligand is inclined to adopt the mode I, where the L ligand can be viewed as a four-connected node (compounds 1, 2, 3, 7, 11, and 13). When one of the θ angles is smaller than 40°, the L ligand is inclined to adopt the mode II, where the L ligand can be considered as a three-connected node (compounds 5, 8, 9, and 12). When two of the θ angles are smaller than 40°, the L ligand is inclined to adopt the mode III, where the L ligand can be regarded as a connecting line (compounds 4, 6, and 10).
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Modes of L

From the structure description above, we can see that the tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L) ligands can bend and rotate freely when coordinating to the central metals due to the flexible nature of the spacers between the four imidazole rings. Though the L ligands act as tetradentate ligands in the compounds 1-13, they display three kinds of different coordination modes (Scheme ). The difference of the coordination modes can be attributed to the discrimination of the Cd-Ccenter-Cd angles (θ) (Scheme ). There are six Cd-Ccenter-Cd angles (θ) among any two Cd(II) atoms and the center carbon atom of L (Ccenter) (Table ). From the angles of the Table  and the structures of compounds 1-13, we can see that when all of the six θ angles are greater than 40°, the L ligand is inclined to adopt the mode I, where the L ligand can be viewed as a four-connected node (compounds 1, 2, 3, 7, 11, and 13). When one of the θ angles is smaller than 40°, the L ligand is inclined to adopt the mode II, where the L ligand can be considered as a three-connected node (compounds 5, 8, 9, and 12). When two of the θ angles are smaller than 40°, the L ligand is inclined to adopt the mode III, where the L ligand can be regarded as a connecting line (compounds 4, 6, and 10).

The anion acts as a key role in determining the structures of the resultant complexes. Through varying the anions under similar synthetic conditions based on the ligand tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L), 13 related Cd(II) compounds with different structures were successfully obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of Anions

The anion acts as a key role in determining the structures of the resultant complexes. Through varying the anions under similar synthetic conditions based on the ligand tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L), 13 related Cd(II) compounds with different structures were successfully obtained.

elements.content: The compounds 1−3 show the effect of inorganic anions (SO4 2−, NO3 −, Br−) on their complex structures. The coordination ability and the size of the inorganic ions influence the θ angles (Table ), which further result in the structural distinction of the compounds 1−3. In 2, the water molecules coordinate to the Cd atoms, whereas the NO3 − anion acts as a free counteranion because of its weak coordination ability. The octahedral Cd centers are linked by the L ligands to yield a 3D 4-connected zeolite ABW net. In compounds 1 and 3, the SO4 2− and Br−, replacing the positions of two coordination water molecules, coordinate to the Cd centers in monodentate mode. The L ligands linked the octahedral Cd centers to generate a 4-connected PtS network and a 2D (44)-sql net, respectively. Obviously, the structural difference of compound 2 relative to 1 and 3 is mainly attributed to the effect of the anion coordination ability. The structure distinction of compounds 1 and 3 shows the effect of the size of anion. The SO4 2− in 1 is a big anion relative to the Br− anion in 3. In compounds 1 and 3, although both the SO4 2− and Br− coordinate to the Cd centers in similar monodentate modes, their overall structures are entirely different.
elements.clean_text: The compounds 1-3 show the effect of inorganic anions (SO4 2-, NO3 -, Br-) on their complex structures. The coordination ability and the size of the inorganic ions influence the θ angles (Table ), which further result in the structural distinction of the compounds 1-3. In 2, the water molecules coordinate to the Cd atoms, whereas the NO3 - anion acts as a free counteranion because of its weak coordination ability. The octahedral Cd centers are linked by the L ligands to yield a 3D 4-connected zeolite ABW net. In compounds 1 and 3, the SO4 2- and Br-, replacing the positions of two coordination water molecules, coordinate to the Cd centers in monodentate mode. The L ligands linked the octahedral Cd centers to generate a 4-connected PtS network and a 2D (44)-sql net, respectively. Obviously, the structural difference of compound 2 relative to 1 and 3 is mainly attributed to the effect of the anion coordination ability. The structure distinction of compounds 1 and 3 shows the effect of the size of anion. The SO4 2- in 1 is a big anion relative to the Br- anion in 3. In compounds 1 and 3, although both the SO4 2- and Br- coordinate to the Cd centers in similar monodentate modes, their overall structures are entirely different.

elements.content: The compounds 4−13 show the influence of organic anions on their complex structures. Generally, the role of carboxylate anions can be explained in terms of their differences in the number of the carboxylate groups, the positions of the carboxylate groups, the nature of the substituting groups, and the flexible abilities of the carboxylate anions. Compounds 4−8 based on dicarboxylate ligands exhibit the effect of the spacer (the length, the flexibility, carboxylate positions, and the substituted group) of the carboxylate ligands on their complex structures. 4 and 5 show the effects of flexibility of the carboxylate spacers. H2L1 and H2L2 are both fatty acid ligands. However, H2L1 has relatively rigid properties because of the existence of a -CHCH- spacer, while H2L2 ligand possesses flexibility owing to the presence of three -CH2- spacers, which allows the two carboxylate groups to bridge the metals from different directions. As a result, [Cd(L)0.5(L1)] (4) exhibits a 2-fold interpenetrating α-Po net, while [Cd5(L2)5(H2O)2]·6H2O (5) shows a noninterpenetrating 3D framework. The compounds 6 and 7 show effects of carboxylate positions on the structures of their complexes. Although both L3 and L4 act as dicarboxylate anions with the rigid benzene ring spacers, the two carboxylate groups of L3 are located in the 1,3-positions of benzene ring, whereas those of L4 are in the 1,4-positions. Consequently, [CdL3(L)0.5] (6) shows a 3D (65·8) CdSO4-type framework, whereas [CdL4(L)0.5(H2O)]·H2O (7) has a different 3D framework with (4·62·72·8)(42·62·7·8) topology. Obviously, the position discrimination of the carboxylate leads to the structural difference of 6 and 7. In addition, the substituted group has an effect on the complex structures. Compared with H2L3, H2L5 has an additional -OH in the 5-position of the benzene ring. [Cd2(L5)2(L)]·2H2O (8) containing L5 displays a 2D layer structure, whereas [CdL3(L)0.5] (6) containing L3 shows a 3D CdSO4-type framework. Distinctly, the existence of the substituted -OH group increases the steric hindrance of the H2L5, resulting in the low dimensional structure of 8. The compounds 9−11 based on tricarboxylate ligands also demonstrate the influence of the carboxylate positions on their complex structures. For H3L6, H3L7, and H3L8, the three carboxylate groups are located in the 1,3,5-, 1,2,3-, and 1,2,4-positions of benzene rings, respectively. In [Cd3(L6)2(L)]·4H2O (9), each L6 ligand coordinates to five Cd atoms in a pentadentate mode, forming a 2D wavelike layer. The layers are further linked by L ligand to generate a complicated 3D structure. In Cd3(L7)2(L)(H2O)2]·2.5H2O (10), each L7 ligand bridges the trinuclear Cd(II) clusters to generate a 2D layer. The L ligands coordinate to two kinds of Cd(II) atoms linking the 2D layers into a chiral 3D α-Po structure. In [Cd(HL8)(L)]·0.75H2O (11), the partially deprotonated HL8 ligand coordinates to Cd(II) center in monodentate chelating mode. The L coordinates to Cd(II) center as a tetradentate ligand, generating a 2D layer structure (Figure b). Clearly, the distinctive structural differences show that the carboxylate positions have an important influence on the networks of the resultant complexes 9−11. Compounds 12 and 13 based tetracarboxylate ligands imply the influence of the spacer length and flexibility of the carboxylate ligands on the resulted frameworks. Although both of H4L9 and H4L10 are based on phenyl rings, the length and flexibility of the spacer are different. The four carboxylate groups of H4L9 are located in 1,2,4,5-positions of one benzene ring, while those of H4L10 are located in 3,3′,4,4′-positions of two benzene rings linked by an -O- group. Thus, the spacer of H4L9 is rigid and not twisted, whereas the two phenyl rings of H4L10 can freely twist around the -O- group bearing flexible abilities to meet the requirements of the coordination geometries of metal ions in the assembly process. In [Cd7(L9)3(μ3-OH)2(L)2]·8H2O (12), the carboxylate groups of L9 anions and the μ3-OH groups link the Cd atoms to generate a Cd-L9 3D framework, and the L ligands further stabilize the 3D structure via Cd−N bonds. In [Cd2(L10)(L)(H2O)2]·H2O (13), each L10 ligand coordinates to the Cd(II) atoms in a tetradentate mode to generate a 2D layer, which is further linked by L ligands to form a 3D framework. Obviously, the structural difference of compounds 12 and 13 is mainly attributed to the effect of the spacer length and flexibility of the carboxylate ligands.
elements.clean_text: The compounds 4-13 show the influence of organic anions on their complex structures. Generally, the role of carboxylate anions can be explained in terms of their differences in the number of the carboxylate groups, the positions of the carboxylate groups, the nature of the substituting groups, and the flexible abilities of the carboxylate anions. Compounds 4-8 based on dicarboxylate ligands exhibit the effect of the spacer (the length, the flexibility, carboxylate positions, and the substituted group) of the carboxylate ligands on their complex structures. 4 and 5 show the effects of flexibility of the carboxylate spacers. H2L1 and H2L2 are both fatty acid ligands. However, H2L1 has relatively rigid properties because of the existence of a -CHCH- spacer, while H2L2 ligand possesses flexibility owing to the presence of three -CH2- spacers, which allows the two carboxylate groups to bridge the metals from different directions. As a result, [Cd(L)0.5(L1)] (4) exhibits a 2-fold interpenetrating α-Po net, while [Cd5(L2)5(H2O)2]⋅6H2O (5) shows a noninterpenetrating 3D framework. The compounds 6 and 7 show effects of carboxylate positions on the structures of their complexes. Although both L3 and L4 act as dicarboxylate anions with the rigid benzene ring spacers, the two carboxylate groups of L3 are located in the 1,3-positions of benzene ring, whereas those of L4 are in the 1,4-positions. Consequently, [CdL3(L)0.5] (6) shows a 3D (65⋅8) CdSO4-type framework, whereas [CdL4(L)0.5(H2O)]⋅H2O (7) has a different 3D framework with (4⋅62⋅72⋅8)(42⋅62⋅7⋅8) topology. Obviously, the position discrimination of the carboxylate leads to the structural difference of 6 and 7. In addition, the substituted group has an effect on the complex structures. Compared with H2L3, H2L5 has an additional -OH in the 5-position of the benzene ring. [Cd2(L5)2(L)]⋅2H2O (8) containing L5 displays a 2D layer structure, whereas [CdL3(L)0.5] (6) containing L3 shows a 3D CdSO4-type framework. Distinctly, the existence of the substituted -OH group increases the steric hindrance of the H2L5, resulting in the low dimensional structure of 8. The compounds 9-11 based on tricarboxylate ligands also demonstrate the influence of the carboxylate positions on their complex structures. For H3L6, H3L7, and H3L8, the three carboxylate groups are located in the 1,3,5-, 1,2,3-, and 1,2,4-positions of benzene rings, respectively. In [Cd3(L6)2(L)]⋅4H2O (9), each L6 ligand coordinates to five Cd atoms in a pentadentate mode, forming a 2D wavelike layer. The layers are further linked by L ligand to generate a complicated 3D structure. In Cd3(L7)2(L)(H2O)2]⋅2.5H2O (10), each L7 ligand bridges the trinuclear Cd(II) clusters to generate a 2D layer. The L ligands coordinate to two kinds of Cd(II) atoms linking the 2D layers into a chiral 3D α-Po structure. In [Cd(HL8)(L)]⋅0.75H2O (11), the partially deprotonated HL8 ligand coordinates to Cd(II) center in monodentate chelating mode. The L coordinates to Cd(II) center as a tetradentate ligand, generating a 2D layer structure (Figure b). Clearly, the distinctive structural differences show that the carboxylate positions have an important influence on the networks of the resultant complexes 9-11. Compounds 12 and 13 based tetracarboxylate ligands imply the influence of the spacer length and flexibility of the carboxylate ligands on the resulted frameworks. Although both of H4L9 and H4L10 are based on phenyl rings, the length and flexibility of the spacer are different. The four carboxylate groups of H4L9 are located in 1,2,4,5-positions of one benzene ring, while those of H4L10 are located in 3,3',4,4'-positions of two benzene rings linked by an -O- group. Thus, the spacer of H4L9 is rigid and not twisted, whereas the two phenyl rings of H4L10 can freely twist around the -O- group bearing flexible abilities to meet the requirements of the coordination geometries of metal ions in the assembly process. In [Cd7(L9)3(μ3-OH)2(L)2]⋅8H2O (12), the carboxylate groups of L9 anions and the μ3-OH groups link the Cd atoms to generate a Cd-L9 3D framework, and the L ligands further stabilize the 3D structure via Cd-N bonds. In [Cd2(L10)(L)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (13), each L10 ligand coordinates to the Cd(II) atoms in a tetradentate mode to generate a 2D layer, which is further linked by L ligands to form a 3D framework. Obviously, the structural difference of compounds 12 and 13 is mainly attributed to the effect of the spacer length and flexibility of the carboxylate ligands.

elements.content: To characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of L·5H2O and 1−13 under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min (Figures S3 and S4 in the ). The specific analysis of the TGA data are listed in the Table . L·5H2O lost its water molecules from 40 to 205 °C (obsd 21.8%, calcd 21.13%). The anhydrous compound begins to decompose at 394 °C. The first weight losses corresponding to the release of water molecules are observed before 227 °C for compound 1 (obsd 8.8%, calcd 9.01%), 163 °C for compound 2 (obsd 7.3%, calcd 5.91%), 387 °C for compound 3 (obsd 3.4%, calcd 2.87%), 126 °C for compound 5 (obsd 5.2%, calcd 6.99%), 266 °C for compound 7 (obsd 6.9%, calcd 7.49%), 283 °C for compound 8 (obsd 5.5%, calcd 3.79%), 262 °C for compound 9 (obsd 5.2%, calcd 6.22%), 248 °C for compound 10 (obsd 7.6%, calcd 6.93%), 309 °C for compound 11 (obsd 3.8%, calcd 2.01%), 331 °C for compound 12 (obsd 6.83%, calcd 6.03%), and 378 °C for compound 13 (obsd 6.02%, calcd 5.64%). The departure of organic components occurred from 545 to 657 °C (compound 1), 348−571 °C (compound 2), 403−645 °C (compound 3), 303−737 °C (compound 5), 343−664 °C (compound 7), 394−522 °C (compound 8), 384−493 °C (compound 9), 377−504 °C (compound 10), 309−586 °C (compound 11), 331−687 °C (compound 12), and 378−534 °C (compound 13). For compounds 4 and 6, the frameworks are stable up to 324 and 352 °C, respectively. The remaining weight of 1−13 may correspond to the formation of CdO.

Luminescent properties of compounds which contain d10 metal centers have attracted more interest because of their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of the neutral ligand L, the carboxylate ligands, and the compounds 1−13 have been studied at room temperature (Figure and Table ). The main emission peak of L is at 435 nm (λex = 365 nm), which may be attributed to π* → π transition. It should be pointed out that the emissions of compounds 1−13 are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature since the Cd2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to their d10 configuration, which are mainly based on the luminescence of ligands. For compounds 1, 2, and 3, the emission peaks appear at 403 (λex = 322 nm), 434 nm (λex = 360 nm), and 388 nm (λex = 339 nm), respectively. These emissions can be essentially ascribed to the luminescence of L ligands. The emission peak of 2 is almost the same as that of free L ligand, which indicates that the inorganic anion NO3 − as a free counteranion has little contribution to the luminescence of the complex. However, the emissions of compounds 1 and 3 exhibit blue-shifts with respect to the free L ligand, which may be attributed to the co-coordination of the L ligands and the inorganic anions (SO4 2− and Br−) to metal centers. Similar to previous reported IIB metal halide/pseudohalide-bipy system and the ZnX2(phen), the π conjugated system of 3 is probably somewhat extended to the bromide atoms; thus, the ligand to ligand charge transfer (LLCT) may also exist in 3. The carboxylate ligands (H2L1, H2L3, H2L4, H2L5, H3L6, H3L7, H3L8, H4L9, and H4L10) used during the syntheses exhibit emissions at room temperature, which can be assigned to the π* → n transition as previously reported. The compounds 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, and 13 show emissions at about 409 (λex = 344 nm), 418 (λex = 360 nm), 435 (λex = 362 nm), 418 (λex = 328 nm), 413 (λex = 322 nm), and 439 nm (λex = 328 nm), respectively. They can probably be assigned to the intraligand π* → π transitions of L ligand because similar emission is observed for the neutral tetrakis(imidazole) ligand. It is considered that the energy transfer may occur from the carboxylate ligands to the L ligand, and therefore, these compounds exhibit the emission of L ligand. Compounds 5, 7, 9, and 10 showing blue-shifts relative to the free L ligand may be attributed to the coordination effects of the ligands to Cd(II) cations, which increases the ligand conformational rigidity and reduces the nonradiative decay of the intraligand. The emission peak of compound 6 at 411 nm (λex = 330 nm) exhibits a weak red-shift with respect to the free ligand H2L3 (403 nm), which may be assigned to the intraligand emission of carboxylate ligand H2L3. It is possible that the deprotonation of H2L3 and the chelating coordination action of the carboxylate anion to Cd (II) ion decrease the π* → n gap of the carboxylate ligand, resulting in the red-shift of the emission peak. For compounds 4, 11, and 12, the emission peaks appear at 480 (λex = 400 nm), 448 (λex = 336 nm), and 445 (λex = 342 nm), showing red-shifts relative to the free L ligand. This may be attributed to the cooperative effects of the neutral ligand and the carboxylate ligands. In a word, the emissions of these compounds originate from the neutral ligand, the carboxylate ligands, or both. In addition, the deprotonation of the carboxylate ligands and the coordination action of the anion and neutral ligand to Cd ions play important roles in the shifts of the emission bands. The emission discrepancy of these compounds is probably due to the differences of ligands and coordination environment of central metal ions, which have a close relationship to the photoluminescence behavior. These results indicate that these polymeric materials may be excellent candidates for highly thermally stable and solvent-resistant photoluminescent material because they are almost insoluble in most common solvents.

elements.content: A series of Cd(II)-containing coordination complexes based on a new tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L) have been successfully prepared by varying the anions under hydrothermal conditions. It has been proven that the tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane is a good candidate for construction of coordination polymers with diverse structures. The structural diversities of the final products show that the anions play an important role in the formation of coordination polymers. The coordination abilities, the length and flexible abilities of the spacers, the numbers and positions of carboxylate groups, and the nature of the substituting groups of the carboxylate anions have significant influences on the resulting structures of the coordination polymers. The photoluminescent emissions show that these complexes may be good candidates for optical materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of Cd(II)-containing coordination complexes based on a new tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane (L) have been successfully prepared by varying the anions under hydrothermal conditions. It has been proven that the tetrakis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)methane is a good candidate for construction of coordination polymers with diverse structures. The structural diversities of the final products show that the anions play an important role in the formation of coordination polymers. The coordination abilities, the length and flexible abilities of the spacers, the numbers and positions of carboxylate groups, and the nature of the substituting groups of the carboxylate anions have significant influences on the resulting structures of the coordination polymers. The photoluminescent emissions show that these complexes may be good candidates for optical materials.

A mixture of imidazole (2.7 g, 40 mmol) and NaOH (1.6 g, 40 mmol) in DMSO (5 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and then pentaerythrityl tetratosylate (7.8 g, 10 mmol) was added. The DMSO were evaporated to dry after the mixture was stirred at 100 °C for 24 h. Twenty-five milliliters ethanol was added to the resulting mixture and filtrated. Then 100 mL of acetic ether was added to the filtrate, and a white solid L was obtained. Then colorless crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were grown by recrystallization from ethanol−water (yield: 86%). Anal. Calcd for C17H30N8O5 (M r = 426.49): C, 47.88; H, 7.09; N, 26.27. Found: C, 47.62; H, 7.21; N, 26.41. IR (cm−1): 3468(s), 3150(w), 1655(s), 1501(s), 1447(m), 1428(w), 1407(w), 1368(w), 1386(m), 1235(s), 1097(s), 1072(w), 1028(m), 915(m), 845(m), 763(m), 730(w), 659(m), 628(m), 537(w).

A mixture of L (16.8 mg, 0.05 mmol), CdSO4·8/3H2O (25.7 mg, 0.10 mmol), and water (10 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL) and heated at 140 °C for 3 days. After the mixture had been cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C·h−1, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained with a yield of 64% (based on CdSO4). Anal. calcd for C34H52Cd2N16O14S2 (M r = 1197.84): C, 34.09; H, 4.38; N, 18.71. Found: C, 34.22; H, 4.26; N, 18.63. IR (cm−1): 3592(w), 3408(m), 3110(s), 1644(s), 1523(s), 1450(m), 1409(w), 1373(w), 1297(m), 1240(s), 1095(s), 930(s), 830(w), 750(m), 661(m), 613(m).

The preparation of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (30.8 mg, 0.10 mmol) was used instead of CdSO4·8/3H2O. Colorless crystals of 2 were collected in a 77% yield (based on Cd(NO3)2). Anal. calcd for C17H24CdN10O8 (M r = 608.86): C, 33.54; H, 3.97; N, 23.01. Found: C, 33.68; H, 3.86; N, 23.12. The preparation of 3 was similar to that of 1 except that CdBr2·4H2O (34.4 mg, 0.10 mmol) was used instead of CdSO4·8/3H2O. Colorless crystals of 3 were collected in a 69% yield (based on CdBr2). Anal. calcd for C17H22Br2CdN8O (M r = 626.65): C, 32.69; H, 3.23; N, 17.94. Found: C, 32.54; H, 3.46; N, 18.02. IR (cm−1): 3515(w), 2472 (w), 1573 (w), 1495 (s), 1104 (w), 859 (m), 721 (w), 654 (w).

To characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of L·5H2O and 1−13 under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min (Figures S3 and S4 in the ). The specific analysis of the TGA data are listed in the Table . L·5H2O lost its water molecules from 40 to 205 °C (obsd 21.8%, calcd 21.13%). The anhydrous compound begins to decompose at 394 °C. The first weight losses corresponding to the release of water molecules are observed before 227 °C for compound 1 (obsd 8.8%, calcd 9.01%), 163 °C for compound 2 (obsd 7.3%, calcd 5.91%), 387 °C for compound 3 (obsd 3.4%, calcd 2.87%), 126 °C for compound 5 (obsd 5.2%, calcd 6.99%), 266 °C for compound 7 (obsd 6.9%, calcd 7.49%), 283 °C for compound 8 (obsd 5.5%, calcd 3.79%), 262 °C for compound 9 (obsd 5.2%, calcd 6.22%), 248 °C for compound 10 (obsd 7.6%, calcd 6.93%), 309 °C for compound 11 (obsd 3.8%, calcd 2.01%), 331 °C for compound 12 (obsd 6.83%, calcd 6.03%), and 378 °C for compound 13 (obsd 6.02%, calcd 5.64%). The departure of organic components occurred from 545 to 657 °C (compound 1), 348−571 °C (compound 2), 403−645 °C (compound 3), 303−737 °C (compound 5), 343−664 °C (compound 7), 394−522 °C (compound 8), 384−493 °C (compound 9), 377−504 °C (compound 10), 309−586 °C (compound 11), 331−687 °C (compound 12), and 378−534 °C (compound 13). For compounds 4 and 6, the frameworks are stable up to 324 and 352 °C, respectively. The remaining weight of 1−13 may correspond to the formation of CdO.

Luminescent Properties

Luminescent properties of compounds which contain d10 metal centers have attracted more interest because of their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of the neutral ligand L, the carboxylate ligands, and the compounds 1−13 have been studied at room temperature (Figure and Table ). The main emission peak of L is at 435 nm (λex = 365 nm), which may be attributed to π* → π transition. It should be pointed out that the emissions of compounds 1−13 are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature since the Cd2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to their d10 configuration, which are mainly based on the luminescence of ligands. For compounds 1, 2, and 3, the emission peaks appear at 403 (λex = 322 nm), 434 nm (λex = 360 nm), and 388 nm (λex = 339 nm), respectively. These emissions can be essentially ascribed to the luminescence of L ligands. The emission peak of 2 is almost the same as that of free L ligand, which indicates that the inorganic anion NO3 − as a free counteranion has little contribution to the luminescence of the complex. However, the emissions of compounds 1 and 3 exhibit blue-shifts with respect to the free L ligand, which may be attributed to the co-coordination of the L ligands and the inorganic anions (SO4 2− and Br−) to metal centers. Similar to previous reported IIB metal halide/pseudohalide-bipy system and the ZnX2(phen), the π conjugated system of 3 is probably somewhat extended to the bromide atoms; thus, the ligand to ligand charge transfer (LLCT) may also exist in 3. The carboxylate ligands (H2L1, H2L3, H2L4, H2L5, H3L6, H3L7, H3L8, H4L9, and H4L10) used during the syntheses exhibit emissions at room temperature, which can be assigned to the π* → n transition as previously reported. The compounds 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, and 13 show emissions at about 409 (λex = 344 nm), 418 (λex = 360 nm), 435 (λex = 362 nm), 418 (λex = 328 nm), 413 (λex = 322 nm), and 439 nm (λex = 328 nm), respectively. They can probably be assigned to the intraligand π* → π transitions of L ligand because similar emission is observed for the neutral tetrakis(imidazole) ligand. It is considered that the energy transfer may occur from the carboxylate ligands to the L ligand, and therefore, these compounds exhibit the emission of L ligand. Compounds 5, 7, 9, and 10 showing blue-shifts relative to the free L ligand may be attributed to the coordination effects of the ligands to Cd(II) cations, which increases the ligand conformational rigidity and reduces the nonradiative decay of the intraligand. The emission peak of compound 6 at 411 nm (λex = 330 nm) exhibits a weak red-shift with respect to the free ligand H2L3 (403 nm), which may be assigned to the intraligand emission of carboxylate ligand H2L3. It is possible that the deprotonation of H2L3 and the chelating coordination action of the carboxylate anion to Cd (II) ion decrease the π* → n gap of the carboxylate ligand, resulting in the red-shift of the emission peak. For compounds 4, 11, and 12, the emission peaks appear at 480 (λex = 400 nm), 448 (λex = 336 nm), and 445 (λex = 342 nm), showing red-shifts relative to the free L ligand. This may be attributed to the cooperative effects of the neutral ligand and the carboxylate ligands. In a word, the emissions of these compounds originate from the neutral ligand, the carboxylate ligands, or both. In addition, the deprotonation of the carboxylate ligands and the coordination action of the anion and neutral ligand to Cd ions play important roles in the shifts of the emission bands. The emission discrepancy of these compounds is probably due to the differences of ligands and coordination environment of central metal ions, which have a close relationship to the photoluminescence behavior. These results indicate that these polymeric materials may be excellent candidates for highly thermally stable and solvent-resistant photoluminescent material because they are almost insoluble in most common solvents.
